Kolumna Mateja Fišerja: Hvala za ribo
Današnje spremembe v medijskem prostoru so tipični primer, ko standardni nasveti ekspertov ne primejo.
02 Nov 2019, 08:33 by Novice



Lokalni ribiči FOTO: M. F.



Propadajoči kompleks Haludovo FOTO: FLICKR


Ko želimo delovati učeno ali pokazati, da smo eden tistih, ki poznajo stoletne resnice in modrosti, se zatekamo k starim rekom ali pregovorom, ko pa želimo biti imenitni, to nadgradimo s kakšno iz slovarja tujk. Vsekakor je treba pred tem dokaj dobro oceniti tistega na drugi strani in ugotoviti, kako daleč lahko gremo z blefom in poliranjem zarjavelih feln, da še vedno ostanemo s kolesi na cesti.Stari japonski pregovor pravi, da če želiš sočloveku pomagati, mu ne daj ribe, ampak ga nauči, kako se riba ulovi. Včasih se mi zdi, da posameznika ni možno ničesar naučiti. Vsak se lahko nauči samo sam, prav zaradi tega sem skeptičen do množice različnih svetovalcev in konsultantov, kot se imenitneje imenujejo, ki prihajajo reševat podjetja in pomagajo pri prestrukturiranju. Na eni strani imajo metodo, neke izkušnje s to metodo, in če prime, je lahko stvar zanimiva, če ne, pa jim le redko uspe razumeti bistvo stvari in narediti resen preobrat, predvsem v panogah, ki imajo svoje specifične skrivnosti ali poslanstva. Mediji so prav gotovo ena takšnih panog, ki je zunaj videti preprosta, v vsakdanjem delovanju pa zahteva veliko človeške, predvsem mentalne energije.Današnje spremembe v medijskem prostoru so tipični primer, ko standardni nasveti ekspertov ne primejo. Izjemno veliko poskusov je bilo, kako ohraniti medije v svoji osnovni obliki, in doslej še nismo iznašli načina, ki bi mu uspelo zagotoviti dovolj prihodka, ki je izgubljen z zmanjšanim povpraševanjem po fizičnih oblikah dostopa do informacij. Na eni strani imamo tradicionalne medije, na drugi pa množico digitalnih, razpršenih vaških portalov, ki vsak na svojem področju pokrivajo ulico ali dve. Vsi ti so konkurenca na trgu podajanja informacij. Obenem poteka izmenjava digitalnih vsebin, kjer se vse skupaj še dodatno zakomplicira in postanejo naslovi tako univerzalni, da ne veš, ali je bila prometna nesreča v tvoji ulici ali v Mehiki. Skratka, ne veš več, kdo je izvor, avtor informacije in komu je v bistvu namenjena.Ribištvo je zelo težavna panoga, težaven posel pravijo nekateri in podobna zmeda se dogaja tudi na tem področju. Prav ribištvo je eden brexitovskih argumentov, mogoče celo primer za vse druge dejavnosti na to temo. Velikim ribiškim korporacijam, ki na eni strani vodijo igro v panogi, je tudi s pomočjo evropske zakonodaje uspelo uničiti množico majhnih lokalnih ribičev, ki skozi generacije lovijo v lokalnem območju. Ko pogledamo posameznika skozi statistike, to niti ni tako pomembno, vendar gre za množico ljudi, ki jim je ribolov v lokalnem območju zagotavljal eksistenco. Kaj pomeni imeti ljudi v nekem lokalnem okolju, neki skupnosti, pa smo ugotovili prepozno. Če ribiška familija ne uspe preživeti na otoku, nekje, kjer je treba živeti z naravo ne samo v turistični sezoni, potem bo to območje prej ali slej postalo degradirano. Ne bo družin, ne bo potrebnih šol, učiteljev, nihče ne bo obdelal zemlje, ne bo treba imeti nič. Niti medijev niti informacij. Res je, da so tovrstne lokacije potem primerne za graditev instant turističnih naselij, ki so v svojih vrhuncih lahko dokaj donosna, in ko se moda spremeni, spet pademo v spiralo, ki terja trd pristanek. In po navadi lokalno okolje s tem izgubi več, kot je pridobilo. Eden takšnih primerov je prestižni kompleks Haludovo, ki je bil v sedemdesetih ponos otoka Krk. Zdaj že več kot štirideset let hromi lokalno skupnost. Pa se spet vračamo k lokalnim ribičem, tistim, ki gredo na morje in znajo ujeti ribo, vendar jo lovijo zgolj toliko, kot je potrebujejo za preživetje lastne družine. Teh lokalnih ribičev nikakor ne moremo narediti iz ljudi, ki so vse življenje ribo dobivali. Lokalne ribiče lahko naredimo zgolj skozi generacije, ki se učijo ribolova skozi veščine. To je to vprašanje iz japonskega pregovora. Kdo je tisti, ki zna ujeti ribo, in tisti, ki je avtor informacije v medijih. To je temelj, na katerem so se razvile panoge in imajo svojo specifiko. Temeljijo na veščinah. Šele tedaj, ko se naučimo ujeti ribo, lahko govorimo o idejah in razvoju. Brez tega so vse samo biznis modeli.

Matthew Fischer's column: Thanks for the fish
Today's changes in the media are a typical example when standard expert advice fails.
02 Nov 2019, 08:33 by Novice



Local Fishermen PHOTO: M. F.



Falling Haludovo Complex PHOTO: FLICKR


When we want to act learned or to show that we are one of those who know the centuries-old truths and wisdom, we resort to old sayings or proverbs, but when we want to be great, we upgrade it with some kind of foreign-language dictionary. In any case, it is necessary to evaluate the one on the other side beforehand and see how far you can go with the bluff and polish the rusty wheels so that you can still stay on the road with your wheels. , but teach him how to fish. Sometimes it seems to me that an individual cannot be taught anything. Everyone can learn only on their own, which is why I am skeptical of the many different consultants and consultants, as they are better known, who come to rescue companies and help with restructuring. On the one hand, they have a method, some experience with this method, and if they do, the thing can be interesting, if not, they rarely understand the essence of things and make a serious turnaround, especially in industries that have their own specific secrets or missions. The media are certainly one such industry that looks simple on the outside but requires a lot of human, especially mental energy in everyday life. Today's changes in the media space are a typical example when standard expert advice is not accepted. There have been many attempts to keep the media in its original form, and so far we have not come up with a way that can provide it with sufficient revenue, which is lost by the diminished demand for physical forms of access to information. On the one hand, we have the traditional media, and on the other, a plethora of digital, scattered village portals, each covering a street or two in their area. All of these are competitors in the information market. At the same time, there is an exchange of digital content, where things get complicated and the headlines become so universal that you don't know if the car accident was in your street or in Mexico. In short, you no longer know who the source is, the author of the information, and to whom it is essentially intended. Fisheries are a very difficult industry, some people say, and similar confusion is happening in this area. Fisheries are one of the Brexit arguments, perhaps even the case for all other activities on the subject. The large fishing corporations, which on the one hand run the game in the industry, have also succeeded in destroying, through European law, the mass of small local fishermen who have been fishing in the local area for generations. When we look at the individual through statistics, this is not so important, but it is a multitude of people who have been provided livelihoods by fishing in the local area. What it means to have people in a local area, or a community, is too late. If the fishing family fails to survive on the island, somewhere where it is necessary to live with nature not only during the tourist season, then this area will sooner or later become degraded. There will be no families, no schools, no teachers needed, no one will cultivate the land, no need to have anything. Neither media nor information. It is true that these locations are then suitable for the construction of instant tourist resorts, which at their peak can be quite profitable, and when fashion changes, we fall again into a spiral, which requires a hard landing. And usually the local environment loses more than it has gained. One such example is the prestigious Haludovo complex, which was the pride of the island of Krk in the 1970s. It has been lame for the local community for over forty years now. However, we are returning to the local fishermen, those who go to the sea and know how to catch fish, but only fish as much as they need to survive for their own family. These local fishermen can in no way be made of people who have been fishing all their lives. Local fishermen can only be made through generations that are learning fishing through skills. This is a question from the Japanese proverb. Who is the one who knows how to catch fish and who is the author of information in the media. This is the foundation upon which industries have developed and have their own specificity. They are based on skills. Only when we learn to catch fish can we talk about ideas and development. Without it all are just business models.
